questions.question: What is an example of a/an ${} factor?

options.mutualism: An association between two organisms of different species in which each member benefits.
options.commensalism: A symbiotic relationship between two organisms of different species in which one derives some benefit while the other is unaffected.
options.parasitism: Interaction between two organisms, in which one organism benefits and the other is harmed.

mutualism: The hermit crab's shell provides a safe haven for anemones. In exchange, the anemone uses its sting to protect the animal from predators.
Humans cannot digest certain foods. Intestinal bacteria feed on these foods and partially digest them.
commensalism: Remora fish painlessly attach themselves to larger marine animals, wait for them to feed, and then detach to take scraps.

Pseuroscorpions attach themselves to exposed surfaces of host animals like the fur of mammals or beneath the wings of beetles and bees. Doing this, receive protection from predators with no nuisance to the sheltering animal.
parasitism: Some insects deposit their eggs within the body of another insect species' larva; when the eggs hatch, the young kill and eat the larva, gaining nutrients from it.
Aphids suck sap off of trees, weakening the plant.

questions.question: What is the definition of a ${}?

options.producer: A living organism which creates its own energy from sunlight
options.consumer: A living organism which must consume other living organisms for energy
options.decomposer: A living organism which recycles nutrients of other living organisms back into the ecosystem

options.independent variable: The variable being changed to affect the outcome
options.dependent variable: The variable that is being studied or measured
options.control group: The group that stays in normal conditions
options.experimental group: The group that receives treatment or change
options.scientific question: A question which includes the I.V. and D.V.
options.quantitative data: Data that can be counted or expressed easily using numbers.
options.qualitative data: Data that cannot be counted or expressed easily using numbers.

questions.question: Which organelle is present in ${} cells?
What is the purpose of the ${}?

options.cell membrane: controls what enters and leaves the cell
options.lysosomes: breaks down and recycles cell waste
options.nucleus: is the control center of the cell
options.cytoplasm: holds all of the organelles in place

questions.question: Which organelle is labeled ${} in the cell diagram?
What is the purpose of the ${} of a microscope?

options.eyepiece: contains the ocular lens and has a magnification of 10x
options.revolving nose: rotates and holds the objective lens
options.arm: is used to hold the microscope when carried
options.light source: provides light through the diaphragm and the specimen

questions.question: Which part is labeled ${} in the microscope?

options.diffusion: movement of molecules from high to low concentration (e.g. oxygen, carbon dioxide)
options.osmosis: movement of water molecules from high to low concentration
options.facilitated diffusion: movement of large molecules from high to low concentration (e.g. glucose)
options.equilibrium: the state when concentration is equal in all areas
options.active transport: movement of molecules from low to high concentration

options.carbohydrates: a chain of sugars used to provide energy to cells
options.fats/lipids: a long molecule used in the cell membrane, brain, and for long-term energy storage

questions.question: What is the purpose of the ${} in the digestive system?
questions.questionReverse: Which organ in the digestive system ${}?

options.mouth: breaks food down by crushing it and with saliva
options.esophagus: receives food from the mouth and delivers it to the stomach
options.stomach: holds food while it is being mixed with enzymes and broken down
options.small intestine: breaks down food more and absorbs it into the bloodstream
options.large intestine: connects the small intestine to the rectum and is the pathway of stool
options.rectum: holds stool until it is ready to be disposed

questions.question: Which part is labeled ${} in the diagram?
What is the purpose of the ${} in the respiratory system?
questions.questionReverse: Which organ in the respiratory system ${}?

options.nasal cavity: is the place where air enters the body
options.epiglottis: guards the entrance to the trachea
options.trachea: is the passageway to the lungs
options.bronchioles: is a small duct that ends in alveoli
options.alveoli: is an air sac and the final destination of air
options.lung: a large, sac-like respiratory organ which occupies the chest cavity

options.arteries: A blood vessel which carries blood away from the heart
options.veins: A blood vessel which carries blood to the heart
options.capillaries: A very small blood vessel which connects arteries and veins

questions.question: How is ${} used in cellular resparation?

options.glucose: Used in glycosis (6) to create 2 pyruvate and 2 ATP
options.pyruvate: Used in Kreb's cycle (2) to create 6 carbon dioxide and 2 ATP
options.carbon dioxide: Created as a byproduct of Kreb's cycle and removed from the cell via diffusion
options.oxygen: Used in the Electron Transport Chain (6) to create 6 water molecules and 32 ATP
options.cytoplasm: The location where glycosis takes place
options.mitochondria: The location where Kreb's Cycle and the ETC take place
